metadata.sermon_title: A Christian Word For Tough Times
metadata.sermon_start_end: One fall Sunday I preached at the venerable and well-known New England women's school, Smith College at Northampton. Along with Wellesley and Holyoke and Vassar, Smith is one of the big four of women's education in this country, dating back to the late 1790s. Here is a community [...] Jesus shall reign where'er the sun Does his successive journeys run; His kingdom stretch from shore to shore, Till moons shall wax and wane no more.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses 2 Timothy 2:3 as a springboard but fails to identify what is unique to this specific text. It quickly devolves into generalities about 'tough times' and 'spiritual warfare' that could be derived from dozens of other passages (Ephesians 6, Psalms, Revelation). The 'NOWHERE else' criterion is not met.
quotes: Here in this passage the martial figure of the soldier is presented as our model.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific context of Timothy as a young leader in Ephesus and the particular 'hardness' (kakopatheson) of the apostolic office, rather than general life hardships.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial. While the Roman military context is mentioned, there is no engagement with the Greek text or the specific theological nuances of the Pastoral Epistles. The preacher relies on a general historical imagination rather than rigorous exposition.
quotes: The world of New Testament Christianity was a world where Roman soldiers moved constantly to and fro as the empire's peacekeepers and garrison watchers.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Analyze the Greek 'kakopatheson' (suffer evil/hardship) to show that the 'hardness' is not just life's 'tough times' but specific suffering for the Gospel.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is broad and covers various life stages (youth, marriage, retirement). It captures the 'zeitgeist' of struggle. However, it often leans toward psychological encouragement rather than the specific 'application of this Bible passage.'
quotes: The middle-aged man or woman who has begun to wonder what is the point of the daily routine... is having a tough problem.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the contemporary struggles more directly to the 'soldier' metaphor's requirement of discipline and single-mindedness mentioned in the verses immediately following the text.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves back and forth between anecdotes and the text, but they often feel like parallel tracks. The hearer is not so much 'expounded' as they are 'comforted' using the text as a backdrop.
quotes: So! There are tough times for all of us... Well, all of us have our tough times spiritually, too.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text's specific logic to dictate the structure of the application, rather than using the text to validate a pre-existing list of human problems.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes 'misery' (tough times, spiritual dryness) and 'redemption' (the victory of the Commander). 'Gratitude' is present in the call for 'enthusiasm' and 'joy' in worship. It successfully avoids a purely objective Christocentrism by centering on the human experience of the battle.
quotes: There are days... when the fire goes out on the altar, leaving an ashen stillness and a dull chill in the region of our hearts.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' section by addressing sin/rebellion rather than just 'tough times' or 'sickness,' to align with the Catechism's depth.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is the weakest point. There is no sense of the 'broad way' or the possibility of being lost. The tone is one of universal triumph and encouragement. The 'seriousness of choice' is replaced by a guarantee of victory.
quotes: Our Commander is a mighty good leader... He goes on before to take the shock of sin and sorrow.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the warning inherent in the soldier metaphor: the possibility of desertion or being 'entangled in the affairs of this life' (v. 4).

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the 'Commander' and the 'telos,' but the sermon flirts with a triumphalist 'King Jesus' theology that risks obscuring the 'grace' found in the weakness of the cross. Christ is more a Victor than a Savior of the lost here.
quotes: Our Commander is the Lord of hosts... nothing is ever settled until it is settled right.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'hardness' the soldier endures to the suffering of Christ, ensuring grace is the 'deepest of our life' rather than just 'victory' at the end.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes (1850 words), the sermon falls just short of Dekkerâ€™s 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth,' opting for many short illustrations rather than one deep theological boring.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section to provide the 'breadth' Miskotte requires, moving beyond anecdotal evidence to theological substance.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily due to a lack of exegetical specificity and the absence of the 'two ways.' It functions more as a motivational speech on resilience than a 'recreation of the Bible into a new, current, proclamatory word.' While it effectively addresses human 'misery' in the form of life's hardships, it treats the biblical text as a thematic ornament rather than the source of a unique, irreplaceable word.
strengths: Strong psychological connection to the audience's lived reality (Thesis 5).
Clear call for an embodied, joyful response to the Gospel (Gratitude).
Effective use of the 'Commander' metaphor to point toward Christ as the telos (Thesis 7).
weaknesses: Lack of specific exegesis; the sermon could be based on almost any 'victory' passage (Thesis 1 & 2).
Complete absence of the 'two ways' or the risk of being lost; it offers a 'vacation' feel despite the 'soldier' language (Thesis 6).
Insufficient length and breadth to achieve theological depth (Thesis 8).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an 'adequate' pastoral address but a 'weak' sermon by Dekker's standards. It fails the formal requirement of being an exposition of a *specific* passage that says what no other passage says. It is too general, too safe, and lacks the sharp edge of biblical particularity.
